key_points: The U.S. Supreme Court is revisiting LGBTQ rights in the case of 303 Creative v. Elenis.
Lorie Smith, a website designer in Colorado, wants to refuse service to LGBTQ customers for same-sex weddings based on First Amendment grounds.
Lambda Legal's Jennifer Pizer expressed concern over the potential for widespread discrimination if the court rules in favor of 303 Creative.
The case echoes previous cases like Masterpiece Cakeshop and Fulton v. City of Philadelphia, which dealt with similar issues of service denial on First Amendment grounds.
Unlike Masterpiece Cakeshop, which involved an actual refusal of service, 303 Creative is preemptively seeking the right to deny services to same-sex couples.
The Supreme Court will focus on the free speech argument, having declined to take up the freedom of religion aspect or to reconsider the Smith v. Employment Division precedent.
Alliance Defending Freedom represents 303 Creative, arguing that forcing the business to serve same-sex weddings violates the First Amendment.
Critics, including Pizer, warn a ruling in favor of 303 Creative could legitimize discrimination against LGBTQ individuals under the guise of free speech.
A friend-of-the-court brief by Dale Carpenter and Eugene Volokh supports 303 Creative's First Amendment claims for expressive goods and services.
The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to let the U.S. solicitor general present arguments on behalf of the Biden administration in this case.
spokespersons: Jennifer Pizer (Acting Chief Legal Officer, Lambda Legal)
Dale Carpenter (Law Professor, Southern Methodist University)
Eugene Volokh (First Amendment Legal Scholar, University of California, Los Angeles)
